name: The Good, The Bad And The Ugly - Screenshots
author: Stagmeister

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello All,

About a year ago, on my first ever thread, several of us shared screenshots of our various creations - sometimes elegantly posed, sometimes action shots, some glamour (though, to be fair, not much evidence of glamour). This gave some some substance to our virtual creations, showed their development, and gave an idea of where they were playing (if you get what I mean), but more importantly, it was fun ("Behold my surging prowess, weakling!", "Be staggered at her mighty tusks!" sort of thing).

Maybe it's something others would be interested in?

I am now confronted with two challenges: i) Establish a link to that thread, so you can see what I mean (feel free to ignore the first few pages, where I merely blather on about the actual build request). I'll try that shortly. And ii) Find where the hell the screenshot button is on my new keyboard, 'cos it sure ain't where it used to be.

For the uninitiated in these things (and me, who's only done two, and those a year ago), here's the sequence for posting a screenshot:

1. Press the Print Screen button - normally near F12 on the keyboard (ooh, just found mine!). You create a bmp screenshot at the same name's folder in the NWN1 folder.

2. Upload to a free web-hosting site - Photobucket or IMGUR (I remember using IMGUR, which was surprisingly easy for an old Luddite).

3. Copy the Direct Link of your pic there and paste on the thread.

I also wrote another note, which reads: "TGA viewer - Fast Stone Image Viewer - change them to png format, which imgur supports." Unfortunately, I have no recollection of what that means, or does. Sorry.

Right, let's try that link... http://nwnecbguild.forumer.com/topic/23 ... uMvM0DOEqg

EDIT: Bugger me, the link works! It does, however, seem ludicrously long. Is there a way of shortcutting these things?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
For a more attractive link, you do something like this, but with square brackets instead of curly ones:
{url=<a href="http://nwnecbguild.forumer.com/topic/23 ... qg}Link</a> to previous thread{/url}
Which will look like this:
Link to previous thread

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Thanks, Empyre - good to know how the more savvy do it! Now all that remains is for me to attempt to upload a shot to show folk what I mean. Gulp.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Tried with an old image and, hoorah, it works! (This is the final battle from HoTU involving my original non-shooty, non-magicky elf.)

I worked out what the TGA viewer thingy was - you need to change your screenshots from a .tga file to a .png one, and that can be done by downloading Faststone Image Viewer.

I'll try a newer image later, all things being well.

Cheers

EDIT: Thought I might as well try it now. This one's from part 2 of Aielund, and features one of Empyre's builds - Order of the Wyrm (unarmed version). Might be worth noting that resting has changed in part 2 - maybe because it's v2.0 (as opposed to 2.01, which the first part was), but it's now 4 hours (8 minutes).

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Forumer won't digest tga's but jpg's are fine (as evidenced by the above) and probably gif's and bmp's as well.

This was the only one I could find left unposted on my photobucket library.  Notice why a wiz/trapper is so powerful.  The combination of BBoD and Skill Mastery makes an encounter like this child's play even for a naked rogue.

BTW... should you ever want to mimic effects contained in other member's posts like reference links, tables, images, etc... Quote the post which contains the effect in a reply, then click the Source icon in the middle of the 2nd row of icons in the editor. (You may need to stretch the window to make the code more readable.) Copy the code that interests you into notepad, make your personal edits, then paste into a new topic. Make sure to close the quoted reply (meaning: Don't save it!).  The mysteries of BB code are only temporary, I assure you.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
You should try it out on the OC just for giggles if nothing else.  You can offset the advantage of hireling inventory-management by adjusting the monster AI as you mentioned.  I like them to equip one of those crafted weapons but leave all the other equipment "as is" just to add a little more interest in finding the reagents and weapons.  That really doesn't change their attack potential very much so it doesn't take much twiddling with the AI to compensate but some of enhancements makes their image look kinda kewl.  I've also wanted to try to get some use out of Boddyknock and Tony's AI makes that possible which is otherwise just an annoying nightmare of micromanagement.  Same for the casters in SoU and HotU.  It really helps.

TBH, out of all the community resources available, I only use CEP 2.3 and Tony's AI.  I'll temporarily add any haks required to play CC, but always copy down the new list of files and delete them when finished.  Call me neurotic but I've had conflicts that screwed up my gaming experience so take measures now.  I also make copies of all the 2das that new CC overwrites and reinstall the originals after my latest venture into custom content.  It may seem like a lot of work or overcompensation but I have never had to hunt down offending haks/overrides ever since adopting this procedure.

Tony K's AI works independently from the game resources so has always been "safe".

@Stagmeister: Max always thought me silly to be playing on WoG with my hardcopy of the build on the desk while he loaded his into his journal.  Problem was: I take lots of notes on my copy, highlight certain choices, make on-the-fly skill allotment changes, jot down what level I begin to face certain monster races, etc. OFTEN so the journal version really adds nothing for me.  Even after explaining all this to him, he still thinks I handle storing build information like a noob... hehehe... Whatever floats your boat, eh?  My boats floats on a sea of beautiful hilite colors, red-penned heiroglyphics and black arrows.  His sea is black with white printing.    But Max kills fewer trees so gets resource conservation points.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Empyre65 wrote:
Also, I switched henchman because Tomi was failing to disable traps too often and dying too often. Now it is Linu who is dying too often. Maybe I would be better off soloing like I usually do.

 
Well, hench really add very little to the experience itself beyond just more meat to attack unlike in HotU where there are convo triggers set all over the 3 modules that are both interesting and funny. 

The best way I've found to get some support from the OC hench is to always place it on Stand Ground, melee weapon or ranged, no difference. Then my toon will begin controlling the situation, maybe splitting or immobilizing a few of the mob.  After it appears the main body is managed, switch the hench to attack nearest.  Tomi usually gets a few easy sneaks in on those I've tied up.   I've yet to lose a single OC hench that way.  But without Tony's AI, Boddyknock is still more of a liability than a valuable companion.  In my experience, Grimgnaw, once permahasted with cold attack and all his monk goodies seems to dominate most encounters.

Oh, and keep dropping Fox pots on Tomi until you get him to at least +2 to disable/search.  I don't recall your final build atm (I seem to remember you using bard mainly as a dump class?), but with Empower and Bard 10+, improving INT skills is even easier.  You may be surprised how many times Tomi is just a point or 2 away from disarming those "problem" traps, typically electrical or fire.

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
PNG uses lossless compression, unlike JPG's lossy compression, so no detail is lost. The forum software shrinks the image to fit the frame, so if your resolution is smaller than mine, it will be shrunk more.

If I right-click the image and select View Image, I see the image full-size (1920x1080). Unless that is a Firefox-only feature and you are not using Firefox, it should work for you, too. It's worth a try. It shows the image sized to fill the browser window with the magnifying glass cursor, so you can make it the true 1920x1080 size by clicking on it, and then you can scroll through the image.

Empyre65 wrote: So far, I am playing mostly like a fighter, with just a little bit of buffing for the tougher fights, similar to how I play Clerics. I am hesitant to summon my animal companion because she takes away some of my experience when we get kills. On the other hand, I wonder if more enemies would appear when she is there, to compensate.
Maybe this helps a bit... I played a pure ranger (who do not get any ECL bonus, unlike a druid) in OC with all my possible companions and summons present most of the time. This means a henchman, an animal companion, a summon, and a dominated animal. I killed Morag at level 16. The encounter system compensates the party size penalty very well, I think you will get roughly the same xp if you keep your whole army beside you all the time. (Or you can exploit the encounter system... spawn the enemies with your full party, then unsummon everyone and get the extra xp for killing more enemies alone.) Of course you get less xp for the fix creatures, like bosses and minibosses, which weren't spawned by an encounter if you kill them with your full party present.

EDIT: by the way, where did you get that golden circlet in chapter one? :O

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Now this is just taking the piss...

I'm in the final part of Mines of Twin Summit and currently at level 37 (Fighter 8/ CoT 2/ DwD 27). I've been petrified by these Magma Elementals, but have 100% fire immunity and am soaking 27/- damage as well as regenerating 12 hps per round and being crit immune. But the icing on the cake is that the armour I'm wearing inflicts electricity damage on a loop to anything hitting me. Thus (and there were 4 of these when I got petrified), all I did was stand still and they all killed themselves while I took precisely 0 damage by the time I unfroze. That's one hell of a defence!



EDIT: It just got sillier. All the underwater dudes (Kua Toa and so on) have a decreased resistance to electricity, so as an experiment I ran up into the midst of them and just stood there - no offensive action whatsoever (I stopped it when AI kicked in) - surrounded by 15 of them. I took no damage at all, but every time one of them touched me all of them took up to 24 electrical damage each. All dead, while I was considering buying a goldfish. It's all very wrong, but it amused me.

I am playing Eye of the Beholder again. I figured out a trick that makes things more convenient. I used a recall potion in the shop near the beginning. Now, the portals in the areas of the game take me to where I last used a recall potion, the shop, so I can unload loot. This is great because it is a long time before I encounter another merchant. The only downside is I have to hoof it all the way from the shop back to where I was. Here I am in the ancient dungeon.

I am wearing a robe intended for sorcerers, but it is not class-limited and it gives 2 AC, 1 better than the Monk robe I had, and with no penalty to Listen skill. I feel silly wearing that garish robe, but function over form.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Not wishing to steal Empyre's thunder, but it's Sands of Fate (hence SoF). You can get it from the Vault. It's one of only two single player modules that I know of that gets you all the way to level 40, the other being Mines of Twin Summit (Aielund is close, reaching about level 36/37). You need to be around level 27/28 to start, so a couple of decent routes are the OC followed by Aribeth's Redemption (though you need to be Good, male and Elf, Half-Elf, or Human for the Aribeth modules), or SoU and HotU. Both of these should get you to the necessary level before starting SoF.

Empyre may well have more to add.

Cheers

posts.author: Stagmeister

Hi there, FG! You seem to have mastered how posting shots works pretty damn well! For anyone less well-versed, the original couple of posts of this thread deal with the technicalities and - almost unbelievably - they're from me!

As to the OC, I can't think of any point where you'd need a henchie, but you might take one for colour and gifts. Tomi's useful as a lock-opener and de-trapper in your early days, and Linu's handy for healing stuff. Daelan's good if you're made of glass and don't do front line stuff. But no one's necessary, particularly as their AI is abominable. I don't know what your main weapon is (unless it really is sling), but if you can grab either a scimitar or greatsword +1 and add some adamantium (iirc) at Marok's forge, that'll give you fire damage, so locks will no longer present a problem. There are only 2 lumps of the stuff lying around - one in No-Man's Land on the way to Blacklake, and the other in Blacklake while undertaking a bit of art theft (so you can use the 2nd to upgrade further in chapter 3). I confess that I tend to do the prison/peninsula first, then No-Man's and Blacklake, because they're my least favourites, so I get the upgrades nice and early. Then I head for the Beggars' Nest and finally the Docks 'cause they're both fun.

You probably know all this already, but I'm bored, so thought I'd share!

Cheers

posts.author: Shia_Luck
posts.content:
Oops, missed this. Apologies for a late reply.

"Lead an army in an epic battle between good and evil, with up to a hundred soldiers on either side!

Give orders to your troops, summon reinforcements, and deploy artillery to support them, as your army strives to capture the enemy's shrines, smash down the gates of their fortress and destroy their altar.

Wage war against the computer, or take the battle online and fight alongside (or against!) your friends. Join either side, as a General or a Hero, with six armies to lead, and eight battlefields to fight over."  (Vault blurb)

So, it's not an adventure with a story, but a Real Time Strategy game. You have an Altar that must survive and the enemy has one you must destroy. You both have a number of shrines which generate mana, and mana is spent spawning your army, buying seige weapons and casting a limited number of healing spells. You can let the AI run your army or you can be the General, deciding which troops to spawn, giving them orders to attack a target, guard your shrines or strategic choke points, or simply come with you as you lead an attack force.

If you aren't a PW player it's a great way to keep your characters alive after their module finishes and even at lvl40 (Tho it does become a case of can you survive dev crit @ lvl40 (so fortification on items is a good idea), and I used it a lot as a place to create a character I had built in excel as I got into learning how (and lurking here for ages ofc ;) ). When you build a character with an impressive spell or special ability DC, you want to use it a lot, no? Bard song and mass buffs from casters come into their own when you're able to influence so many troops. With the exception of the social skills, everything can be useful. I even have an effective Harper Scout there.

The author, John 'Gestalt' Bye, actively encourages modding it and provides a step by step guide to building your own maps etc. I wanted to make it less about dev crit and make it even more about your character and what they can do at high levels so started modding the armies and abilities and making new maps etc, and ended up making all sorts of changes. So the screenies I posted are from my version. I'll take some when in a battle and post them.

https://neverwintervault.org/project/nw ... s-evil-iii

Have fun :)

Thing is, the difference with NWN and DnD is that you generally dont get 4-6 ish people playing together as the original DnD was conceived, (even in PWs IME, (Once we got 8 of us in a quest party and ofc there were DM events where lots would meet up, but playing GvE with friends was the only other time I got 8 people playing together.)  (tho I never tried slow levelling, full RP, no OOC chat servers. Not my thing. Maybe it works there.) Anyway, a healer build, for example, is a weak choice in a party of you and a henchie or a couple of friends .. but in the context of an army at war, you can make a significant difference. Many RP builds are weak choices, yet can be incredible in that war context (If you go where you are needed to support, attack, defend etc).

In fact, it could be a great place to experiment with a caster build.. you know, if you were an out and out meleer and wanted a nice environment to learn how to fight with one *Cheeky grin* (Sorry, but as a caster, how can I not join in the 'get Stag to play a caster' campaign? *grin*)

Have fun :)

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
Here I am having just arrived in Aqualis.
I need to explain what I did to the gloves.  I imported the character from the end of LoT into Pretty Good Char Creator and edited the Hellmouth gloves, which has Deflection AC +3, Attack Bonus +8, 15 Fire Damage, 50% Fire Immunity, and Vorpal DC 14.  I removed the AC bonus and the fire immunity, and downgraded the 15 Fire Damage to 2d10 Acid Damage, and then added Haste and +3 Regeneration, and upgraded the Attack Bonus to +10, leaving the Vorpal DC 14 property as-is.  The PGCC says that this is a level 25 item and i was level 27, so it is level-appropriate.

Both Lord of Terror and Sands of Fate use CEP, but PGCC does not, so I lost my gem pouches and whatever was in them, so here is how I fixed that.  I started a new game in SoF with the character with the edited gloves, dropped the gloves, and saved the game.  Then I started a multiplayer session, loaded the saved game, imported the character from the end of LoT, picked up the gloves and saved the game again.  When I loaded the game in single-player, I had both the edited gloves and the gem pouches.

The additional damage you see is from the nice upgrade you get near the beginning of SoF chapter 2 to your weapon, or in this case, Monk gloves, which is honestly the main reason I wanted to play an unarmed character in SoF.
